title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Exclusive: Senior US state department officials have moved to mollify concerns about the pace of coronavirus vaccinations for employees, acknowledging there has been “some confusion” about the distribution of the jabs.

In a February 2 memo to staff, Antony Blinken, secretary of state, said the department had requested 315,000 doses of Covid-19 vaccines for employees, eligible family members and contractors but had so far received just 47,050 doses, about 15 per cent of the amount requested.

“The department is one of several federal agencies receiving vaccine allotments due to our national security mandate,” said the cable, adding that the decisions on who gets it “are not, and have not been, easy decisions”.

The memo, which was marked sensitive and has been seen by the Financial Times, said the state department was set to receive enough doses to vaccinate 13,200 more people this month. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • US stocks hit new records on Thursday as investors looked for signs of progress on Joe Biden's planned $1.9tn stimulus. A sell-off in 30-year Treasuries has pushed the country's yield curve to its steepest level in more than five years. Republicans are divided over whether to support the plan.

  • Johnson & Johnson filed an application seeking emergency use authorisation for its Covid-19 vaccine from the Food and Drug Administration, bringing the company one step closer to getting the first single-shot vaccine distributed in the US.

  • The worldwide shortage of semiconductors is forcing Ford to cut production next week at two plants making its bestselling F-150 pick-up truck. German carmakers are considering stockpiling semiconductors to avoid shortages.

  • The UK is set to introduce mandatory quarantine for arrivals from a “red list” of countries from February 15.

  • Emmanuel Macron's political future hangs in the balance amid a slow vaccine rollout and the prospect of a third nationwide lockdown.

  • Covax, the global initiative for equitable access to Covid-19 vaccines, has published its plan for the distribution of 337m jabs. (FT, AJ)

Simon Kuper argues to spend whatever it takes on wartime-style mobilisation to make, distribute and inject vaccines — and save the world from long Covid-19. Keep up with the latest on our live blog.

In the news

US to withdraw support for Yemen war Joe Biden said the US would end its support for the war in Yemen, marking a break with six years of military assistance from Washington for the Saudi-led coalition that is fighting Iran-linked rebels in the impoverished Arab country. The announcement follows a decision by the White House to suspend arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. (FT)

Trump rejects request for impeachment trial testimony Donald Trump's lawyers have rejected House Democrats' request for the former president to testify under oath in his Senate impeachment trial next week.

  • The US House on Thursday voted to strip Republican lawmaker Marjorie Taylor Greene of her committee assignments over her espousal of conspiracy theories.

  • Snap has warned that the Capitol insurrection by a pro-Trump mob could slow ad momentum after brands curbed digital spending in January. (FT)

Former US cyber chief calls for military to attack hackers Chris Krebs, the ex-head of the US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, has called for the military to target organised criminal gangs of hackers who launch ransomware attacks on companies and governments. (FT)

Nordstrom brothers confident of overcoming trouble in store Nordstrom cannot only survive the current economic turmoil, but emerge with faster growth and a business model relevant to more of America's increasingly demanding shoppers, Erik and Pete Nordstrom insisted in an interview with the Financial Times. (FT)

News media bosses bow out as frantic Trump era ends The departure of Donald Trump from the White House has ushered in a changing of the guard for the news business that feels almost as climactic. Reuters, The Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, HuffPost, Wired and Vox Media — are all looking for new editorial chiefs. (FT)

CVC in talks to buy stake in San Antonio Spurs The Luxembourg-based buyout group is seeking a stake of about 15 per cent in the club owned by the Holt family which founded the Caterpillar industrial vehicles company, according to several people with knowledge of the discussions. The investment would value the basketball team at $1.3bn. (FT)

Kuaishou shares surge on IPO Shares in Chinese streaming video platform Kuaishou nearly tripled on their first day of trading in Hong Kong on Friday, delivering a massive windfall for the chief rival to TikTok. (FT)

Merck chief executive to retire Kenneth Frazier, one of only a handful of African-American chief executives of Fortune 500 companies, will retire from his post as Merck chief executive this summer, and will be replaced by the drugmaker's executive vice-president Robert Davis. (FT)

Wall St firms paid almost $3bn last year for retail brokers' trades Wall Street trading firms paid almost $3bn to retail brokers such as Robinhood to handle their trades last year — a lucrative practice which is attracting attention in Washington. (FT)

The days ahead

US non-farm payrolls The US economy was expected to show a small rebound in job creation last month after a dip in December. According to the consensus of economists' forecasts heading into Friday's report by the US labour department, non-farm payrolls were projected to show a gain of 50,000 in January, with the unemployment rate unchanged at 6.7 per cent. (FT)

Ecuador election The country is set to hold elections for a new president and legislature on Sunday. Lenín Moreno, the incumbent, is not seeking re-election. (FT)

US Super Bowl The biggest American football game of the year takes place on Sunday, but the pandemic is taking the shine off the Super Bowl for some of the most prominent commercial advertisers. (FT)

What else we're reading

How Silver Lake won big at AMC Inspired by ideas on Reddit, spread on Twitter and executed by retail traders, the surge in the shares of US cinema chain AMC Entertainment last week broke new ground on Wall Street. But the big winner was a well-established private equity firm: Silver Lake Partners.

  • Who are the final winners of the Robinhood saga, Gillian Tett asks.

  • The sight of retail money pouring into equities when valuations have already risen substantially is historically a warning sign that a market top beckons, Michael Mackenzie writes. (FT)

Unilever unshackled Alan Jope, chief executive of Unilever, one of the world's largest consumer goods makers, is facing pressure to give the group a pandemic-fuelled revival after unifying its almost century-old Anglo-Dutch structure into a single, UK-domiciled company last year. Can it become a nimbler player in mergers and acquisitions? (FT)

How to take on Covid conspiracy theories During the first great pandemic of the digital age — Covid-19 — the spectre of a shadow plague has haunted us: the unstoppable rise of health disinformation. As vaccines are rolled out around the globe, we are more vulnerable than ever to conspiracy theories, writes David Robert Grimes. (FT)

British fashion raises the alarm on Brexit trade deal More than 450 leading figures from the UK's fashion and textile business this week wrote to Boris Johnson warning that the UK-EU trade deal risked the “decimation” of the industry. “It's been an absolute disaster,” said Ben Taylor, co-founder of the British knitwear brand Country of Origin. (FT)

Interview with outgoing US ambassador of South Korea Harry Harris, the outgoing US ambassador in Seoul, reflects on the Trump presidency and orchestrating the June 2019 Trump-Kim meeting at the demilitarised zone separating the Koreas. “To go from nothing, to ‘let's have a summit' . . . it was pretty exciting, pretty heady.” (FT)

Video of the day

Hong Kong under the national security law Since Beijing imposed a wide-ranging security law on Hong Kong in June 2020, the government has cracked down on the city's education sector, media and political life. Nicolle Liu looks at how the law is being used to change civil society. (FT)
